newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Ringgit gains slightly on dollar/majors weakness.
newsitem.headline: Ringgit gains slightly on dollar/majors weakness.

text.p: * Ringgit up on fresh demand from Malaysian corporates
* Dollar selling by exporters at 2.5090 helps ringgit
* Ringgit gains seen limited by selling vs Sing dollar
The ringgit was marginally higher on Tuesday morning on dollar selling by exporters and corporates, dealers said on Tuesday.
They said the gains were limited by selling against the Singapore dollar, which started on Monday evening in London.
"There was a big sell order on ringgit/Sing in London. When that happened dollar/Sing collapsed and dollar/ringgit shot up," said a European bank dealer in Singapore.
"At the same time one big party, funds related, sold dollar/ringgit. From then on it was bidded all the way up."
The dealer said technically too the ringgit was due for a rebound soon. "It could come before the week ends," he said.
A dealer with another European bank in Singapore said people were trading both ways in a very narrow range.
He said there were some Malaysian exporters selling dollars at 2.5090 and speculators were picking up dollars around 2.5070.
"If the 2.5110 level holds for the next couple of days, then we should see dollar/ringgit moving down," the dealer said.
He said the selling of dollar/Sing was mainly by U.S. funds, who had built up positions in anticipation of the New York Commodities Exchange launching futures contracts in Asian currencies.
But, the NYCE has postponed the launch of dollar/Sing futures contract, partly due to pressure from Singapore.
"This is causing many to dump dollar/Sing," he said.
Thai baht, ringgit and Indonesian rupiah futures contracts are expected to be launched by
At 0330 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.5085/95 a dollar.
